content: UZIO is an all-in-one HR, payroll, benefits, and time platform that centralizes people operationsâ€”covering payroll and tax, HRIS, benefits, time and attendance, expenses, compliance, and reporting. UZIO Co-Pilot is an in-app AI assistant that answers questions, automates routine actions, and guides admins through complex HR, payroll, and benefits workflows to reduce time-to-completion.
generated_questions: What is UZIO and which core HR and payroll functions does it centralize?
How does UZIO Co-Pilot help admins with HR, payroll, and benefits workflows?
Which areas of people operations can be managed within the UZIO platform?

content:
UZIOâ€™s Time Tracking and Scheduling module lets teams capture time exactly where work happensâ€”on the web, in the employer and employee portals, the UZIO mobile app, or a shared time kiosk. Employees clock in and out, record meals and rests, and see their hours in one place, while managers get a clean review flow for daily checks and end-of-period approvals. Everything is designed to be quick for frontline users and auditable for admins, reducing corrections and speeding up payroll.

Break compliance is built in. You can define paid and unpaid meal and rest policies, set eligibility thresholds and repeat rules, and choose whether to auto-deduct or simply flag missing breaks for attestation. This gives you the flexibility to match local laws and company policies without forcing a one-size-fits-all rule across teams. When exceptions occur, they are visible and traceable so you can correct issues before they reach payroll.

Scheduling is just as streamlined. Managers create and publish shifts, make updates, and ensure coverage across locations or roles. Employees see their assigned shifts on web and mobile as soon as schedules are published, helping reduce no-shows and last-minute confusion. Simple controls keep the learning curve low so planners can move quickly even during high-change periods.

Managers can publish open shifts for eligible employees to claim on mobile. Employees can offer their assigned shift to co-workers or request a swap; these actions route to managers for approval or rejection, and once published, updates hit everyoneâ€™s calendars. Eligibility rules, such as requiring the same work location, are enforced so coverage changes stay compliant and auditable.

Manager workflows tie the whole process together. You can monitor who is on the clock right now, review timesheets for your direct reports, approve or send back changes, and sync hours to payroll when they are final. Because time and schedules live in the same system as HR and payroll, data flows forward with fewer exports, fewer manual edits, and a clear audit trail from shift plan to time worked to payroll.
generated_questions: What channels can employees use to clock in and out or record breaks in UZIO?
How does UZIO handle break compliance, missed breaks, and attestation?
What scheduling capabilities like open shifts and swaps does UZIO provide for managers and employees?

content:
UZIOâ€™s Time Off module gives employees a clear, self-service experience to request time off, check balances and track history from the web and the UZIO mobile app. On web, employees select Request Time Off, enter dates and reasons, and see their current balances before submitting. On mobile, time off lives in the bottom navigation so people can request from anywhere without emailing HR.

For admins, policies and holidays are centralized and configurable. You can add and manage time-off policies, then assign them to employees; holiday calendars are created from the same area so observed holidays flow into balances and availability. This keeps policy rules and holidays consistent across teams and locations.

The approvals flow is built in. Employees submit requests; managers are notified and can approve or deny with notes. Admin dashboards let you review pending requests at a glance, reducing email back-and-forth and keeping decisions auditable. That visibility cuts down on surprises at payroll time and makes it easy to enforce blackout dates or staffing minimums.

Time Off is wired to payroll and scheduling. Approved PTO and unpaid time off sync to payroll and, for salaried employees, regular hours adjust automatically when unpaid time is used. If your PTO accrues off hours worked, using UZIO for both payroll and PTO ensures automatic accrual calculations without manual reconciliation. This end-to-end flow moves you from policy to request to approval to pay with fewer errors.

How are time-off policies, holidays, and approvals managed by admins and managers?
In what ways is the time-off module integrated with payroll and scheduling?

content:
UZIO Payroll starts with clean setup so every run is predictable. You define pay groups and pay schedules (weekly, bi-weekly, semi-monthly, and so on), pick first pay dates, and make sure your payroll calendar aligns with benefits cut-offs so per-pay-period deductions calculate correctly. Once company and banking details are in place, this foundation prevents most downstream errors and makes reviews faster.

Running payroll follows a guided flow: load hours and earnings, review taxes and net pay, then approve. You can handle regular payrolls and special or off-cycle runs such as bonuses or corrections, and a recent enhancement lets admins process regular and special payrolls at the same time when timelines are tight. The system also documents how bank holidays impact timing so you can plan approvals and funding with confidence.

Admins can fine-tune results without breaking auditability. Common tasks include salary proration, overriding deduction or contribution methods, and making targeted employee payroll updates (earnings, deductions, contributions, direct-deposit changes for employees without portal access, and similar actions). These controls help you correct edge cases in the current cycle while keeping the underlying setup stable for future runs.

Taxes and year-end are built into the flow. UZIO documents how tax payments (impounds) are scheduled and debited relative to check dates and due dates, so finance teams can reconcile cash movement. On the employee side, the help center explains the W-2 form and provides guidance for downloading W-2s, with updates noting mobile access as well. For bonuses or gift cards, gross-up tools calculate the necessary tax to land a target net.

Accounting and reporting close the loop. UZIO offers a two-way QuickBooks Online integration with per-component mapping (earnings, employee deductions, employer taxes and contributions) and clear syncing rules such as syncing after approval. Finance users can also build custom payroll reports to analyze costs, taxes, and liabilities over time. Together, these features reduce spreadsheets, keep the ledger in sync, and make audits straightforward.

content:
UZIOâ€™s Hire and Onboarding module brings candidates into your system with minimal back-and-forth. You can add a prospective employee, choose whether the employer completes the forms or send a self-onboarding invite so the candidate fills in their details, and then track progress from a single status view. This two-path approach, employer-driven or self-service, keeps momentum up while giving admins full visibility.

On the hiring side, you can configure offer letters and supplemental documents (handbooks, policies) once and reuse them across roles. If your workflow includes screening, UZIO documents an integration with Checkr for background checks, and for work authorization there is a built-in integration with Clear I-9 to manage I-9 and E-Verify for onsite or remote hires. These pieces reduce manual steps and keep sensitive compliance tasks inside one flow.

The Documents area acts as your onboarding content library. Admins can add custom employee documents, organize them with custom categories, and point managers to the exact place to upload or assign paperwork from the employer portal.

Tasks make the process trackable. A task is a to-do with a due date and owner; your task library centralizes onboarding, offboarding, and ongoing tasks so you can reuse checklists. You set up onboarding and offboarding task lists in settings, assign them to the right people, and monitor completion as part of each hireâ€™s statusâ€”no spreadsheets required.

content:
UZIOâ€™s Benefits module digitizes the entire benefits lifecycle for employers, brokers, and employees so you can configure plans, publish packages, and manage changes year-round without paper forms. Employers get a guided setup to approve and share benefit packages, brokers manage plan design and servicing across their book, and employees enroll online and can update coverage when eligible as new hires, during open enrollment, or for life events.

Plan building is structured and reusable. You can load plans and rates (medical, dental, vision, and others), define eligibility classes by role or location, and set contribution strategies such as fixed dollar amounts, percentages, and dependent tiers. A decision support system helps compare plan designs so you can present the right mix by cost and coverage before publishing packages.

Enrollment is built for real life. Admins can run new-hire enrollments, open enrollment, and mid-year enrollments when adding clients or moving groups mid-cycle. The enrollments dashboard shows participation and completion status and lets you monitor progress.

Renewals are streamlined. At plan year change you can roll over coverage and select replacement plans where necessary, then monitor the impact through enrollment and financial dashboards for cost visibility. On the employee side, help articles confirm that workers enroll from the portal and can access their elections and premiums at any time; mobile FAQs reinforce that eligibility and enrollment happen through the employee portal.

Finally, benefits data does not live in a silo. The UZIO payroll system automatically pulls deductions and contributions from benefits and processes them in payroll.

This portal is where setup decisions such as pay schedules, policies, and roles turn into day-to-day actions.

content:
Employer administrators or any user in the company who has been granted the permission 'Schedule and Time Tracking Settings' can manage the schedule and time tracking configurations for the company. To grant this permission follow the steps
Login as Employer Admin.
Open Manage Users from the left navigation menu
Locate or add the role and go to Company Access and find the setting Schedule and Time Tracking Settings.
Set the permissions as required
No Access- No access to manage schedule and time tracking settings.
View Access- View access to schedule and time tracking settings. The user can view the settings but cannot make any changes, manage geofence, schedule settings or time tracking settings.
Full Access- Full access to schedule and time tracking settings. The user can view as well as change the settings, manage geofence, schedule settings or time tracking settings.

section_title: Scheduling Grid and Its Key Features
content: The Scheduling grid is a tabular layout where employer users can view and manage shifts for employees. Each row typically represents an employee, job, or work location depending on the selected view, and each column represents a specific day or time period. The grid allows you to create, edit, copy, publish, and manage shifts as well as act on groups of shifts, such as the entire schedule.

Work Location
Department
Job Title
Pay Group
Pay Type

You may combine multiple filters at once to narrow results to a specific subset of employees or shifts. Filters remain in effect until you clear them, and the grid updates in real time.

content:
The system provides multiple views of the scheduler grid and also allows switching between views so you can see schedules in the way that best fits your planning needs. You can view by employee, by work location, or by job. Each view changes what each row represents.
Employee view: Each row is an employee; the shift bars in the row show the shifts for that employee on the selected day or time range.
Work Location view: Each row is a location; the shift bars in the row show the shifts for all employees of the location on the selected day.
Job view: Each row is a job; the shift bars in the row show the shifts for employees assigned to that job. “Uncategorized Job” shows the shifts that are not tagged with any job.
This flexibility facilitates the user to view the shifts of the desired employees or groups in the most meaningful layout.

content: In the Week view, the scheduler grid shows a full week at a time, with each column representing a day of the week and each row representing an employee, job, or location depending on the selected view. This view helps managers understand weekly staffing patterns, identify coverage gaps, and ensure that weekly hour or wage targets are being met.

content:
With the help of this feature, you can estimate the total cost of scheduled shifts directly from the scheduler grid. When Show Cost is enabled, the system calculates the cost of each shift based on the employee’s pay rate.
If the shift is associated with a job, then the total cost of a shift is calculated based on the hourly pay rate of the respective job for the respective employee.
If the shift is not associated with any job, then the total cost of the shift is calculated based on the primary job (shown on the Job Page of the employee profile).
This allows managers to quickly gauge labor spend for a day, week, or location from the grid.

content: With the help of this feature, you can estimate the total hours scheduled directly from the scheduler grid. When Show Hours is enabled, the system calculates the total hours of shifts per employee, per day, or for the entire visible schedule. To derive the hours, the system uses the start and end times of each shift and sums up the hours of all the shifts showing in the column.\nThis helps managers ensure that employees are not under-scheduled or over-scheduled and that total hours align with staffing plans.

As shifts are created, the scheduler compares the scheduled hours and wages with the set budget, enabling managers to monitor variances and control labor costs.\nThis helps ensure that scheduling decisions stay within financial targets while still meeting operational coverage needs.

content: To create shifts for multiple days in bulk, UZIO provides a repeat or recurrence option while creating the shift. After defining the base shift (employee, date, time, job, location), you can enable the option to repeat the shift and choose the recurrence pattern—such as daily, weekly, or on selected weekdays like Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. You can also specify an end date or number of occurrences. UZIO then automatically generates all matching shifts, allowing you to build recurring schedules quickly without individually creating each shift.

content: The Notes field on a shift is an optional free-text area where you can add additional comments or instructions. Examples include special tasks to be completed during the shift, coverage notes, location details, hand-off instructions, or any other context that might help employees and managers understand the purpose of that shift. Notes are saved with the shift and can be viewed later when reviewing or editing the schedule.

content: There are several important rules to keep in mind when creating shifts. First, simply creating a shift does not make it available for time tracking; it must be published before employees can see it and use it for clock-ins. Second, you can create shifts for any day, even if it falls on a holiday or conflicts with an employee’s time off—the system does not automatically block those days. Third, UZIO prevents overlapping shifts for the same employee to avoid conflicts. You can, however, create multiple non-overlapping shifts for the same employee on a single day, and you can also create overnight shifts that start on one date and end on the next.
generated_questions: Do employees see newly created shifts immediately, or do they need to be published in UZIO?
Can I create shifts on holidays or days when employees have time off assigned?
What are the rules around overlapping or multiple shifts for a single employee in one day?

content: UZIO supports shifts that start on one calendar day and end on another, such as overnight or multi-day assignments. Employers can define a shift whose end time falls on the following day. For very long multi-day coverage needs, it is usually recommended to break the assignment into separate daily shifts—for example, one shift ending at 11:59 PM and another starting at 12:00 AM the next day—so that hours, budgets, and notifications remain accurate and easy to manage. This approach also simplifies downstream time tracking and payroll calculations.

Why is it recommended to split very long multi-day assignments into daily shifts?
How do multi-day shifts affect budgeting and time tracking in UZIO?

content: Schedule Import is an additional way to create shifts in bulk using an Excel template. From Time Tracking → Schedule, employer users can click the Schedule Import icon to download the current Schedule Import template. Each row in the template represents one employee shift, with columns for employee, date, times, job, work location, and other shift details. By default, the template is pre-populated based on employees you have access to and default shift settings in Schedule Settings, and imported shifts are created in a default color unless specified otherwise. After you fill out or modify the template, you upload it back into UZIO. The system validates each row, creates valid shifts, and generates an error file in the File Center for any rows that failed, including reasons for failure. Imported shifts are created in an unpublished state; you must publish them before employees can track time against them. Bulk import supports creating shifts in bulk but does not support editing existing shifts in bulk.
generated_questions: How do I use the Schedule Import Excel template to create many shifts at once?
What information must I provide for each row when importing shifts into UZIO?
What happens to invalid rows and the publication status of shifts after a schedule import?

content: Publishing is the step that makes scheduled shifts visible and actionable for employees. After shifts are created—either manually or via import—they are initially in an unpublished state. UZIO allows you to publish individual shifts or publish many shifts in bulk. Publishing a shift changes its status from draft to live so that employees can see it in their schedule views (web, mobile, or kiosk) and use it for time tracking. Until a shift is published, it will not be used for employee notifications, budgeting comparisons, or clock-in validations.
generated_questions: What does it mean to publish a shift in UZIO Scheduling?
Why are new shifts created in an unpublished state instead of being live immediately?
What impact does publishing have on whether employees can see and track against a shift?

content: To publish a single shift, you click directly on the shift in the scheduler grid and choose the Publish option from the actions available. UZIO updates the shift’s status to Published and the change is reflected visually on the grid. Once published, the shift becomes visible to the assigned employee in their schedule views and can be used for clock-in, clock-out, and related notifications according to your settings.
generated_questions: How do I publish a single shift directly from the scheduler grid in UZIO?
What visual or status changes indicate that a specific shift has been published?
When a specific shift is published, how does it appear to the assigned employee?

content: To publish many shifts at once, you can use the Publish button at the top of the Schedule page. When you click this button, UZIO publishes all currently visible unpublished shifts on the grid. The scope of this action depends on your filters and search criteria: if you filtered the schedule by department, location, job, or other attributes, only the shifts in that filtered view will be published. This lets you publish by segment, such as one department or location at a time. If you want to publish all shifts across the company, you should clear filters and searches before using bulk publish.
generated_questions: How does bulk publishing of shifts work in the UZIO scheduler?
Which shifts are included when I click the Publish button on the Schedule page?
How do filters and searches affect which shifts are published in bulk?

content: When publishing shifts in bulk, UZIO automatically checks for overlapping shifts for each employee. If it detects that some of the shifts you are trying to publish overlap with existing published shifts, it flags these conflicts. Valid, non-conflicting shifts are still published, while overlapping ones remain unpublished. The system provides a message indicating that overlaps were found and identifies the problematic shifts so you can review and adjust them. After resolving the overlaps, you can attempt to publish those shifts again.
generated_questions: What happens if overlapping shifts are detected when I bulk-publish schedules in UZIO?
Does UZIO publish any shifts if some of them are overlapping during a bulk publish?
How can I find and correct shifts that failed to publish due to overlap detection?

content: You can edit an existing shift by clicking on it directly in the scheduler grid and selecting the Edit option. This opens the shift details, where you can adjust fields such as date, time, job, work location, assigned employee, and notes. Edits apply to both published and unpublished shifts, subject to certain restrictions. Once changes are saved, they are applied immediately and reflected across all schedule views where that shift appears (employee, job, or location views).
generated_questions: How do I edit an existing shift from the UZIO Schedule page?
Which shift attributes can be changed when editing a shift?
Do changes to a shift take effect immediately across all schedule views?

content: When editing shifts, there are some important limitations and behaviors. You can edit both published and unpublished shifts, but if a shift already has time entries recorded and approved, certain fields may be locked to preserve data accuracy. You can change the shift date, but moving a shift may create conflicts if the employee already has another shift for that period; UZIO will enforce rules against overlaps. You can also reassign a shift to another employee, which updates who sees and works that shift. All allowable changes are applied instantly once saved and are reflected in scheduling and reporting.

content: Deleting Shift refers to removing one or more shifts from the schedule. UZIO allows you to delete a single shift, delete all shifts currently visible on the scheduler grid, or clear only unpublished shifts. Deleting shifts removes them from employee views and from the scheduler while preserving any historical time data where required. Some shifts cannot be deleted if they already have time entries recorded and approved, to maintain payroll and compliance integrity.
generated_questions: What options does UZIO provide for deleting shifts from the schedule?
How does deleting a shift affect what employees see on their schedules?
Under what conditions might a shift be protected from deletion in UZIO?

content: To delete a specific shift, click directly on that shift in the scheduler grid and choose the Delete option. UZIO will ask for confirmation before removing the shift. Once confirmed, the shift is removed from the scheduler and is no longer visible to the employee for tracking. Both published and unpublished shifts can be deleted, but shifts that have associated time entries—especially those already used for payroll—may be protected from deletion to preserve data accuracy.
generated_questions: How do I delete a single shift from the UZIO Schedule page?
Do I need to confirm before a specific shift is deleted from the scheduler?
Can I delete shifts that already have recorded time against them in UZIO?

content: You can delete an entire schedule view—meaning all shifts currently visible on the scheduler grid—using the appropriate bulk delete action. This removes both published and unpublished shifts within the current filter and date range. Shifts that already have time entries recorded for them are not deleted, even in a bulk delete, to protect payroll and historical records. After the deletion completes, the grid refreshes and a confirmation message indicates that the visible schedule has been cleared. This is useful when you need to wipe and rebuild a schedule for a period.
generated_questions: How can I delete all shifts in the current schedule view in UZIO?
Which shifts are affected when I use the bulk delete or delete entire schedule option?
Are shifts with existing time entries removed when I delete the entire schedule?

content: Clear Unpublished Changes is a bulk action designed to remove only unpublished shifts from the scheduler grid. When you select this option, UZIO deletes all currently visible shifts that are in an unpublished state, leaving published shifts intact. As with other bulk actions, filters and search criteria determine which shifts are visible and therefore affected. Shifts that already have time entries recorded are not removed, to maintain data integrity. This feature is useful when you want to roll back draft scheduling changes without disturbing the live schedule.
generated_questions: What is the difference between deleting the entire schedule and clearing unpublished changes?
Which shifts are removed when I use Clear Unpublished Changes in UZIO?
How do filters and searches affect the Clear Unpublished Changes action?

content: UZIO allows you to download the schedule in two primary formats: PDF and Excel (XLS). These downloads are generated from the scheduler grid and respect your current filters, date range, and view, giving you an offline, shareable snapshot of planned shifts. PDF is useful for quickly printing or sharing a visual schedule, while Excel is better suited for further analysis, reconciliation, or importing into other tools.
generated_questions: In what formats can I download the UZIO schedule from the scheduler grid?
Do schedule downloads respect the filters and date ranges applied on the scheduler?
When should I choose PDF versus Excel for exporting the UZIO schedule?

content: When you choose the Download Schedule as PDF action, UZIO generates a PDF representation of the current schedule view. The PDF includes all relevant shifts from the scheduler—published shifts, unpublished shifts, and open shifts—based on your filters and date range. This is typically used to print schedules for posting in shared locations or to send a static copy to managers or employees who need a visual reference.
generated_questions: What information is included when I download the schedule as a PDF in UZIO?
Does the PDF schedule show only published shifts or also unpublished and open shifts?
How can a PDF download be useful in communicating schedules to employees?

content: The Download Schedule XLS action exports the current schedule view into an Excel file. UZIO runs a Shift Assignment report behind the scenes, using the same filters and search criteria that are applied on the scheduler grid. The exported Excel file lists each shift with details such as employee, date, times, job, work location, and status in a structured tabular format. Once the export is ready, UZIO provides a download link at the top of the screen and also stores the file in the File Center so you can retrieve it later. This format supports deeper analysis, reconciliation with payroll, or integration with other reporting tools.
generated_questions: What does the Download Schedule XLS option export from the UZIO scheduler?
How does UZIO determine which shifts to include in the Excel schedule export?
Where can I access previously generated XLS schedule reports after export?

content: The Copy Shift feature lets you quickly duplicate existing shifts instead of building new schedules from scratch. From the scheduler grid, you can use the Copy icon or action to choose how you want to copy shifts: copy the current view forward to the next period, pull a schedule from a previous period into the current one, or use an advanced option to copy from any custom range to another. This is especially useful when weekly patterns repeat or when you want to reuse prior schedules as a starting point.
generated_questions: How does the Copy Shift feature help speed up schedule creation in UZIO?

content: Copy to Next duplicates all shifts currently visible on the scheduler grid into the next period, based on your active view. If you are looking at a Day view, the shifts are copied to the next day; in Week view, they are copied to the next week; and in Month view, to the next month. This allows you to roll a schedule forward one period at a time while preserving your filters so that only the relevant department, location, or group is copied.
generated_questions: What does the Copy to Next option do in the UZIO scheduler?
How does the behavior of Copy to Next differ by Day, Week, or Month views?
Do filters affect which shifts are included when using Copy to Next?

content: Copy from Previous pulls the schedule from the previous day, week, or month (depending on the current view) and replicates those shifts into the current period. This is helpful when schedules are stable over time and you want to reuse a prior period’s pattern. As with other copy options, filters and search criteria determine which shifts are brought forward, letting you copy schedules for a specific group, location, or department.
generated_questions: How does the Copy from Previous option work on the UZIO Schedule page?
Can I copy only certain employees or locations when using Copy from Previous?
When is it useful to copy schedules from a previous period into the current one?

content: The Advanced Option for copying shifts offers the most flexibility. It allows you to specify any prior date range (day, week, or custom span) as the source period and then choose a target date range where the shifts should be duplicated. You can also control which employees, jobs, or locations are included by using filters and dropdown selections. This is ideal for maintaining complex, repeating patterns or reusing a successful staffing plan for a different time window, while still being able to fine-tune which parts of the schedule are copied.

How can I define custom source and target date ranges when using the Advanced copy option?
In what scenarios is the Advanced copy option better than Copy to Next or Copy from Previous?

content:
An Open Shift is a shift that is not assigned to any specific employee and is available for eligible employees to claim. Open shifts are created against one or more work locations, and any active employee belonging to those locations can view and request them. Once a claim is approved, the shift is assigned to that employee and behaves like a regular shift for time tracking and approval.

To create an Open Shift, employer users use the same Add Shift workflow on the scheduler grid. They can either double-click a cell or click the plus (+) icon in the grid to open the shift creation window. In the Assignee dropdown, they select 'Open Shift' (instead of a specific employee) and then choose one or more work locations. If multiple locations are selected, the system creates one open shift per location so people at those locations can see and claim them.

Employees can only claim open shifts from the mobile app. From the Schedule tab, they go to Open Shifts → Available Shifts to see all unassigned shifts available for their work locations. They tap the Claim link on a shift they want; this creates a claim request that is sent to the admin for review. Until the admin approves, the shift remains unassigned and stays in a pending status.

Employees can also manage their pending claims from Open Shifts → Requested Shifts in the mobile app. There they see all open shifts they have claimed that are still waiting for approval and can cancel a claim via a three-dot menu → 'Cancel Request.' Cancelling removes their claim and makes the shift available again to other eligible employees.

Admins review and decide on open shift claims directly from the scheduler. Clicking the shift and choosing the Claims action opens a list of employees who have requested that open shift. The admin can accept or reject each request. When they accept one employee's claim, the system automatically rejects all other pending requests for that shift, assigns the shift to the accepted employee, and notifies everyone involved with appropriate emails and/or push messages (e.g., an email confirming approval with shift location, time, and date).
generated_questions: What is an Open Shift in UZIO Scheduling and how is it different from a regular assigned shift?
How can an employer create an Open Shift for one or more work locations in the scheduler grid?
What is the end-to-end flow for an employee to claim an Open Shift from mobile and for an admin to approve or reject that claim?

content:
A Shift Swap allows two employees to exchange their assigned shifts, subject to eligibility rules and manager approval. The main constraint is that employees can only swap shifts with coworkers who belong to the same work location. This ensures coverage and compliance remain intact while still giving employees flexibility to handle personal conflicts or preferences.

Employees initiate a swap from the UZIO mobile app (this is not available on web). They open the Schedule tab, go to My Shifts, and use the Swap link on the shift they want to exchange. This opens a window showing shifts of other employees at the same location. The requesting employee selects one or more target shifts and then taps the Swap Shift button, sending swap requests to the selected coworkers.

The coworkers receive notifications via email and push, including details of both parties' shifts (times, dates, and any comments). Each recipient reviews the request in the mobile app under Schedule → Shift Requests → Swap → Incoming Requests, and can Accept or Reject it. If they accept, the requester is notified that the swap is now pending manager approval; if they reject, the requester is notified that the swap was declined.

Employees can manage their own outgoing swap requests under Schedule → Shift Requests → Swap → 'Your Requests'. From there, they can cancel any pending swap request, which keeps the original schedule unchanged. After an employee has accepted a swap request from someone else, they can still change their mind and cancel that accepted request via the Incoming Requests view; this triggers a notification back to the requester.

Admins finalize shift swaps from the scheduler in the employer portal. Using the Needs Approval icon, they open Shift Swap Requests to see pending swaps, including both employees and their shift details. The admin can Accept or Reject each request. Shifts are not actually exchanged until the admin approves. Once a decision is made, both employees are notified, and on approval their schedules are automatically updated. The system also sends email templates summarizing approved or rejected swaps, including details such as shift times, dates, and optional comments from the requester or accepter.
generated_questions: How does the Shift Swap flow work in UZIO from the employee’s perspective on mobile?
What eligibility rules and approvals are required before two employees can successfully swap their shifts?
Where can admins view, approve, or reject pending shift swap requests in the UZIO scheduler?

content:
Offering a Shift is a workflow where an employee can offer their assigned shift to other employees at the same work location, again subject to manager approval. Unlike a swap, where two employees directly exchange shifts, a shift offer is more like giving away a shift to someone who currently has no shift at that time.

Employees initiate an offer from the mobile app only. From Schedule → My Shifts, they choose a shift and tap the Offer link. A window appears listing coworkers from the same work location who are eligible to take the shift (i.e., those who do not already have a conflicting shift). The employee selects one or more coworkers and taps Offer Shift to send requests.

Selected coworkers receive email and push notifications with details about the offered shift, and they manage responses via Schedule → Shift Requests → Offer → Incoming Requests. Each coworker can Accept or Reject the offer. Accepting an offer sends a confirmation to the original requester and notifies the admin that a shift offer is pending approval; rejecting sends a different notification to the requester saying their offer was declined.

Employees who initiate offers can manage their outgoing requests under Schedule → Shift Requests → Offer → 'Your Requests'. For each pending offer, they can open the three-dot menu and select Cancel Request; cancelling keeps their original shift assignment intact.

The admin’s role mirrors the swap flow: they review pending offer requests from the scheduler using Needs Approval → Shift Offer Requests. Admins can approve or reject each offer. On approval, the system updates schedules so the offered shift moves from the original employee’s schedule to the accepting coworker’s schedule. Both employees receive notifications about the final decision, and email templates summarize approved and rejected offers with shift details such as date, time, and any comments.
generated_questions: What is the difference between swapping a shift and offering a shift in UZIO Scheduling?
How does an employee offer a shift to coworkers using the UZIO mobile app, and where do they track their outgoing offers?
What does the admin approval flow look like for Shift Offer requests, and how are employees notified of the outcome?

content:
Schedule Notifications allow UZIO to keep both employees and managers informed about shift events, punctuality, and no-shows via email, push, and SMS. The system supports different notification types for employees and managers that can be configured in the Schedule Settings.

For employees, notifications include:
- Reminders to start shift on time: A reminder is sent shortly before the scheduled start time to prompt the employee to clock in. A sample push notification message might say that a shift from 09:00 AM–06:00 PM is about to start and list the employee’s name.
- Reminders to end shift on time: A similar reminder is sent near the scheduled end time, encouraging the employee to clock out.
- Notification of shift publish: When a manager publishes shifts, employees receive notifications informing them that new or updated shifts are available to view.
- Alerts for early or late shift start and early or late shift end: If an employee starts or ends outside the configured threshold around the schedule, the system sends an alert. This helps employees quickly understand when they are off their planned schedule.
- No show alerts: If an employee does not clock in at all by a certain time relative to the shift start, a no-show alert can be sent, often summarizing missing employees by name and shift.

For managers, similar notification types exist with a managerial perspective:
- Alerts when employees do not start or end their shift on time (within configured thresholds).
- Alerts for early or late starts and ends across the team, so supervisors can see deviations from schedule.
- No show alerts summarizing employees who failed to clock in for a given shift window.

These notifications can be sent in multiple channels (email, push, and SMS). Sample templates include a subject line (e.g., 'Alert: Few employees have missed their shift 09:00 AM - 06:00 PM'), a body listing affected employees, and a link directing managers to log in and review schedules. This helps maintain real-time visibility and rapid response to attendance issues and schedule adherence.
generated_questions: What types of schedule notifications can employees receive in UZIO (e.g., reminders, early/late alerts, no-show alerts)?
How do managers get notified when employees miss a shift or do not start/end their shifts on time?
Can UZIO send schedule-related notifications via email, push, and SMS, and what information do these messages typically contain?

content:
Schedule Settings give admins fine-grained control over how scheduling interacts with time tracking, especially around clock-in/clock-out behavior and default shift patterns. These settings are managed from the employer portal under Time Tracking Settings → Schedule.

Key settings include:
- Prevent Early Clock In: When enabled, employees are blocked from clocking in earlier than a configured threshold before their scheduled shift start time. For example, with a 15-minute threshold and a 9:00 AM start, employees cannot clock in before 8:45 AM for that shift. This helps control unplanned overtime. The restriction applies only to scheduled shifts; if an employee clocks in under 'Unscheduled,' this guardrail does not apply, allowing flexibility when someone works outside their schedule.
- Mark Late Clock In: This flag automatically marks a time entry as 'Late' when an employee clocks in after a defined threshold from the scheduled start time (e.g., after 9:15 AM for a 9:00 AM shift with a 15-minute window). This supports punctuality tracking and reporting.
- Default Shift Timings: Admins can define default shift start and end times (e.g., 9:00 AM–5:00 PM). These defaults pre-populate when creating new shifts, speeding up schedule creation while still allowing users to override for specific cases.

Employee Experience of Schedule on Web: Employees log into the UZIO employee portal and navigate to Time Tracking → Schedule. The page displays their assigned shifts, timings, and related details for the selected period. They can switch views between day, week, and month to see their schedule at different granularities.

Employee Experience of Schedule on Mobile: In the UZIO mobile app, employees tap the Schedule tab in the bottom navigation. The view is split into:
- My Shifts: Shows assigned shifts by day and supports actions such as Swap and Offer where enabled.
- Open Shifts: Contains Available Shifts (unassigned shifts at the employee’s work location that can be claimed) and Requested Shifts (open shifts the employee has already claimed and that are pending approval).
- Shift Requests: Centralizes both Swap and Offer workflows with two sub-sections each:
  - Swap: Incoming Requests (others asking to swap with you) and Your Requests (swaps you have initiated).
  - Offer: Incoming Requests (shifts offered to you) and Your Requests (offers you have sent).

This configuration plus the web and mobile views gives employees full transparency into their schedule and related actions, while admins maintain control over how closely actual time tracking must follow the plan.

What are Default Shift Timings and how do they speed up schedule creation for admins?
How can employees view and manage their schedules, open shifts, and shift requests on both the web portal and the mobile app?

content:
Time Tracking is an add-on. Submit a request from the employer portal to enable it before you can configure or use it. Sign in to the employer portal and open Time Tracking from the left navigation. On the Time Tracking landing page, click “I am Interested” to submit the activation request to UZIO. UZIO reviews and enables the Time Tracking module for your company. Once UZIO has enabled it, log out and log back in so that the new module becomes visible.
After Time Tracking is enabled, employer users who have the full access to company level “Scheduling and Time Tracking Settings” will see Time Tracking settings under the left navigation. From here, you configure the module for your organization and then start using it for time capture and payroll.
generated_questions: What does 'Enable Time Tracking' mean in the context of UZIO Time Tracking?
How do I work with 'Enable Time Tracking' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Enable Time Tracking' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

content:
Configuring Time Tracking is a one-time, guided setup available only after the module has been enabled for your company. The goal is to align how time is captured and measured in UZIO with your company’s policies so that you can accurately calculate hours and pay. To begin, log in as an employer user with full access to “Scheduling and Time Tracking Settings,” open Time Tracking from the left navigation, and click Get Started, then complete the following steps.
In the configuration flow, you will: (1) add employees to Time Tracking, (2) set up overtime rules and assign them to employees, (3) create break rules (for meals and rest breaks) and assign them, (4) configure geofencing at work locations, and (5) configure schedule-related settings, if Scheduling is enabled. Once these steps are complete, you can move on to day-to-day use of timesheets, approvals, and payroll.
generated_questions: What does 'Configuring Time Tracking' mean in the context of UZIO Time Tracking?
How do I work with 'Configuring Time Tracking' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Configuring Time Tracking' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

content:
Begin by adding employees to Time Tracking. Click into Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation and go to the Employees tab. From there, click the “Select Employees” button to choose active employees who should be allowed to use time tracking. Only active employees can be added.
You can add employees individually or in bulk, based on filters such as work location, department, or pay group, depending on your setup. Once selected, employees are enabled for time tracking and will begin to appear in timesheets, kiosk, or mobile views according to their permissions and your configuration. If you remove an employee from Time Tracking, they will no longer be able to record time and will not appear in new timesheets.
If you are also using Scheduling, this step controls which employees will appear on the scheduler grid. Employees must be added into Time Tracking and Scheduling to be visible for shift assignment. In addition, employees need to have a valid work location and (if required by your configuration) a wage or pay rate and a calendar; employees without a calendar will not be allowed for selection.
generated_questions: What does 'Adding Employees' mean in the context of UZIO Time Tracking?
How do I work with 'Adding Employees' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Adding Employees' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

content:
Set how overtime is calculated, then assign the right rules to employees. In Time Tracking Settings, open the Overtime tab and create the overtime rules that match your legal requirements and company policy—for example, daily overtime after 8 hours, daily double time after 12 hours, or weekly overtime after 40 hours. Once rules exist, you assign them to employees or groups so that UZIO can automatically calculate overtime on their timesheets.
Assignments can be done by work location, department, or other criteria depending on your filtering options. You can assign one or multiple rules per employee, as needed (for example, combining daily and weekly overtime rules). UZIO then applies these rules when calculating overtime hours on timesheets, summaries, and payroll exports. Note: Overtime rules apply to non-exempt employees. Exempt salaried employees are typically excluded by company policy.
generated_questions: What does 'Overtime Rules Assignment' mean in the context of UZIO Time Tracking?
How do I work with 'Overtime Rules Assignment' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Overtime Rules Assignment' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

content:
Define how employees take and record breaks by creating Break Rules, then assign them to employees. On the Break Rules tab under Time Tracking Settings, you configure rules that describe break types (e.g., meal, rest), their durations, timing windows, and any compliance checks. No break rules exist by default—and employees cannot record or be evaluated for compliant or non-compliant breaks until at least one rule is created and assigned to them.
After defining a break policy, you click Add Break Rule, configure the policy details, save, and assign it to the appropriate employees or groups (for example, all non-exempt employees in California). Assignments control which employees are subject to which break rules. These rules then inform how the system analyzes and displays break entries in employees’ timesheets and break compliance reports.
generated_questions: What does 'Break Rule Assignment' mean in the context of UZIO Time Tracking?
How do I work with 'Break Rule Assignment' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Break Rule Assignment' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

content:
Set location-based clocking boundaries with Geofencing. Define geofences so that employees can only clock in or out when they are within an allowed radius around a work location. This helps prevent off-site punches and improves the accuracy of time capture.
To configure, go to Company Settings or work locations, select the work location you want to enforce geofencing on, edit it, enable the geofence option, and set the geofence radius/area on the map. Save the location. Once enabled, UZIO uses the employee’s mobile device location when they attempt to punch in or out and can block or warn about punches that fall outside the geofence, depending on your settings.
generated_questions: What does 'Geofence Setup' mean in the context of UZIO Time Tracking?
How do I work with 'Geofence Setup' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Geofence Setup' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

content:
Configure Scheduling only if the Scheduling module is enabled (it becomes available after Time Tracking is enabled). Schedule Settings determine how closely time tracking must adhere to the posted schedule. From Time Tracking Settings → Schedule, you can configure features like preventing early clock-ins, flagging late clock-ins, and default shift timings.
You may also define how shifts and time entries interact—for example, whether employees are allowed to clock in for unscheduled work, whether clocks must always be tied to a scheduled shift, and how tolerances around shift start/end times are treated. These settings help ensure schedule adherence while still allowing flexibility when needed. Save your changes to apply them across the roster.
generated_questions: What does 'Schedule Settings' mean in the context of UZIO Time Tracking?
How do I work with 'Schedule Settings' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Schedule Settings' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

content:
Time Clocks are the mechanisms employees use to record their time. UZIO supports multiple clocking methods, including the web-based employee portal, the UZIO mobile app, and shared devices configured as Kiosks. Depending on your configuration, employees can clock in, clock out, and record breaks from one or more of these devices.
In Time Tracking Settings, you define which clocking options are available to employees and whether any additional controls apply, such as restricting clocking to geofenced locations, requiring job selection at clock-in, or allowing unscheduled punches. You also determine whether employees are allowed to edit their own time entries or if all changes must be done by managers. Your choices here shape the day-to-day employee experience and the level of control you maintain over time capture.
generated_questions: What does 'Time Clocks' mean in the context of UZIO Time Tracking?
How do I work with 'Time Clocks' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Time Clocks' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

section_title: Roles and Permissions for using Time Tracking
content:
Roles and Permissions control who can configure Time Tracking, who can see which employees’ time, and who can approve or modify entries. These are managed from the employer portal under Manage Users, where you define roles such as Payroll Admin, HR Manager, Supervisor, and so on, and then assign Time Tracking–related permissions to each role.
Typical permissions include: access to Time Tracking Settings (company-level configuration), access to manage employee timesheets, access to approve time for specific employees or locations, and access to run time reports. By carefully assigning these permissions, you ensure that only appropriate users can change configuration or edit time records, while supervisors and managers have the visibility and control they need for their teams.

section_title: Managing Employer Settings of Time Tracking
content:
To view or manage company-level Time Tracking information, employer users with the right permissions open Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation. From here, they manage overtime rules, break rules, geofencing, schedule settings, timesheet behavior, and which employees are enabled for time tracking.
This is where you define how time tracking behaves across the organization—selecting which clocking methods are allowed, setting up rules for premiums and rounding, defining who can approve time, and configuring integration points with payroll. Updates made in this area affect all covered employees, so they should be handled by admins who understand both company policy and compliance requirements.

How do I work with 'Managing Employer Settings of Time Tracking' when using UZIO Time Tracking?

content:
To view or manage timesheets of accessible employees, employer users go to Time Tracking → Timesheets from the left navigation. The main grid shows employees, the relevant pay period, and high-level hours. Clicking into an employee opens their detailed timesheet for that period, where you can review, edit, or approve entries depending on your permissions.
You can add or edit daily time entries (clock-in, clock-out, breaks), adjust projects or jobs associated with time, and correct errors such as missed punches. Once reviewed, timesheets are approved to lock them down and make them ready for payroll. Additional information may be available through an Employee Timesheet link under Additional Information, which shows detailed status and history of approvals.

How do I work with 'Managing Employee Timesheet' when using UZIO Time Tracking?

content:
An employee can use the UZIO time tracking module only if they meet certain criteria: the employee must be active in the system, added to Time Tracking, and (if Scheduling is used) have an appropriate schedule or access setting. To manage which employees are included, employer users open Time Tracking Settings and go to the Employees tab.
From there, they can select employees to add to or remove from Time Tracking, typically using filters like work location, department, or employment type. This page acts as the control center for who appears in timesheets, who can clock in or out through kiosks or mobile app, and who shows up on the scheduler grid. If an employee is removed from Time Tracking, their historical time data remains for reporting and payroll, but they cannot record new time going forward.

How do I work with 'Managing Employees for Time Tracking' when using UZIO Time Tracking?

content:
To add active employees into the time tracking module, follow the steps:
1. Locate the Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation.
2. Go to the “Employees” tab on the right.
3. Click on the “Select Employees” button.
4. Use filters (such as work location, department, or pay group) to narrow the list.
5. Select the employees you want to add and save.
Only active employees can be selected. Once added, they will appear in the time tracking views (timesheets, kiosks, mobile) and can begin recording time according to your configuration. If needed, you can return to this page to add newly hired employees or remove terminated employees from Time Tracking eligibility.

How do I work with 'Adding Active Employees' when using UZIO Time Tracking?
What steps or settings are described under 'Adding Active Employees' in the UZIO Time Tracking guide?

content:
If an employee should no longer use Time Tracking—such as when they are terminated, moved to a role that does not record time, or are no longer hourly—you can remove them from Time Tracking. In Time Tracking Settings → Employees tab, locate the employee or group of employees you want to remove and use the “Remove Employee” or equivalent action.
Removing an employee prevents new time entries for that employee and removes them from the active lists in timesheets and scheduler, but it does not delete historical data. Past time entries remain available for reporting, payroll history, and audits. This keeps your records intact while ensuring only appropriate employees can continue to clock in, clock out, or appear on active timesheets.

content:
Overtime Rules define how and when time worked transitions from regular time to overtime or double time. UZIO lets you configure rules to match statutory and company policies, such as daily overtime after a certain number of hours, daily double time after a threshold, weekly overtime beyond a standard workweek, and seventh consecutive day rules.
These rules are configured in Time Tracking Settings under the Overtime section. You define the parameters (e.g., daily overtime start after 8 hours, weekly overtime start after 40 hours) and then assign them to employees. UZIO uses these rules when evaluating total hours on timesheets to categorize regular, overtime, and double time hours correctly for reporting and payroll.

How do I work with 'Overtime Rules' when using UZIO Time Tracking?

content:
Weekly Overtime Start After Hours is a parameter within an overtime rule that specifies the number of hours an employee must work in a workweek before overtime hours begin accruing. For example, in many jurisdictions weekly overtime starts after 40 hours worked in a single week.
When you configure an overtime rule, you enter the weekly threshold in this field. UZIO then evaluates the total hours an employee works during the defined workweek and treats hours beyond the threshold as weekly overtime. This works together with daily overtime and other rules to accurately calculate total overtime hours.

content: Daily Overtime Start After Hours is a setting inside an overtime rule that specifies how many hours an employee must work in a single workday before the remaining hours in that day are treated as overtime. For example, if you set this to 8 hours, then the first 8 hours in a day are regular time and any hours worked beyond 8 in that same day are paid at the overtime rate (unless they qualify for double time under another rule). This lets you comply with daily overtime requirements in states where overtime is calculated on a per-day basis, not just per week.

section_title: Daily Double Overtime Start After Hours
content: Daily Double Overtime Start After Hours defines the daily threshold after which hours are treated as double-time instead of regular overtime. For example, you might pay regular time up to 8 hours, overtime from 8 to 12 hours, and double time for any hours beyond 12 in a single day. In UZIO, you enter the double-time threshold (such as 12) in this field, and the system automatically classifies hours beyond that point as double-time hours on the employee’s timesheet and in payroll exports.

content: 7th Consecutive Day Overtime is a setting used for jurisdictions where overtime rules apply when a non-exempt employee works seven consecutive days in the same workweek. When enabled, the rule looks at each employee’s workweek and, if they have worked at least one hour on each of the first six days, automatically applies overtime and/or double time on the seventh worked day based on the local requirements. For example, some rules pay time-and-a-half for the first 8 hours on the 7th day and double time after 8 hours on that day. UZIO uses this configuration to categorize that seventh-day time correctly on timesheets.

content: The Assign To section of an overtime rule lets you apply that rule to specific employees or groups in bulk. From the Overtime Rules tab you select the rule, then choose which employees it should cover using filters such as work location, department, pay group, or employment type. Once assigned, UZIO uses that rule whenever those employees’ timesheets are evaluated, so their hours are split into regular, overtime, and double time according to the configuration. You can adjust assignments over time as employees move locations or roles.

content: Employers can edit overtime rules when policies or regulations change. To update a rule, go to Time Tracking Settings, open the Overtime Rules tab, locate the rule, and click Edit from the Actions menu. You can change items such as the workweek start day, weekly and daily overtime thresholds, daily double-time thresholds, and 7th consecutive day settings. After you save, the updated rule applies to future time entries. Existing historical time entries are not automatically reprocessed, so past payrolls remain unchanged unless you deliberately adjust them.

content: If a rule is no longer needed—for example, after decommissioning a policy or replacing it with a new one—you can delete the overtime rule from Time Tracking Settings → Overtime Rules. After locating the rule, you use the Delete action. UZIO will prevent deletion if the rule is still in active use in ways that could break historical records, such as being linked to current employees or required for past payroll reporting. When a rule is successfully deleted, it is unassigned from employees and will no longer be available for new calculations; existing time entries remain as they were and are not reprocessed.

content: Overtime pay is additional compensation owed to non-exempt employees when they work beyond the limits defined by law or company policy. Under the U.S. Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), standard overtime is typically paid at one-and-a-half times the employee’s regular rate of pay for all hours worked over 40 in a workweek, and many states add daily or seventh-day overtime requirements on top of that. UZIO’s overtime rules engine is designed to model these regulations so that overtime hours on timesheets are correctly calculated and passed to payroll for payment at the appropriate overtime or double-time rate.
generated_questions: How does UZIO define overtime pay for non-exempt employees?
What is the typical overtime multiplier used under FLSA and how is it reflected in UZIO?
How do overtime rules in UZIO help ensure compliance with federal and state overtime laws?

content: Blended overtime, also known as weighted average overtime, applies when an employee works at two or more different pay rates during the same workweek. Under the FLSA, overtime must be calculated from a regular rate that reflects a weighted average of all rates and hours worked, not just one job’s base rate. In practice, this means you first calculate the total straight-time wages for all jobs in the week, divide by the total hours worked to get a blended regular rate, and then compute overtime premiums from that blended rate. UZIO supports blended rate scenarios so that overtime pay is calculated correctly when employees work multiple jobs or roles with different hourly rates.
generated_questions: What are blended (weighted average) overtime rates and when do they apply?
Why can’t I just use one job’s hourly rate when calculating overtime for an employee with multiple rates?
How does UZIO handle overtime when an employee works in two or more positions at different pay rates?

section_title: When is a Blended Rate Required and Example Calculation
content: A blended rate is required when an employee works at more than one pay rate in the same workweek and becomes eligible for overtime. Instead of paying overtime off a single base rate, you must compute a weighted average of all the employee’s straight-time earnings and hours. For example, imagine an employee works 30 hours as a Driver at $10/hour and 20 hours as a Cleaner at $20/hour in a week where 5 of those hours are overtime. First you calculate total straight-time wages: (30 × $10) + (20 × $20) = $700. Then you divide by total hours worked (50) to get a blended regular rate of $14/hour. The overtime premium is half of that blended rate ($7), so the blended overtime rate for each job is the job’s base rate plus $7 (e.g., Driver OT = $17, Cleaner OT = $27), and similarly, blended double time uses twice the blended regular rate added to each job’s base. UZIO uses this approach to allocate overtime and double-time wages correctly across each job’s hours so that total pay complies with weighted-average requirements.

content: Break Management in UZIO defines how employees’ meal and rest breaks are configured, tracked, and evaluated for compliance. Using Break Rules, you can codify your company’s paid rest and unpaid meal policies, decide how missed or short breaks are handled, and optionally configure premiums, notifications, and break attestations. This allows you to standardize behavior across locations and roles, support state-specific rules (such as California meal and rest break requirements), and reduce payroll and compliance disputes.

content:
Break Rules define your paid rest and unpaid meal policies—types of breaks, minimum durations, eligibility windows, and how missed or short breaks are treated. To create a break rule in UZIO:
- Open Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation.
- Go to the Break Rules tab.
- Click the “Add Break Rule” button.
In the Add Break Rule window, you enter the descriptive details of the break (code, name, category, type, duration, eligibility window, and any auto-deduct or premium behavior). Once saved, the Break Rule becomes available to assign to employees or groups so that their time entries can be evaluated against the defined policy.

It should clearly communicate which type of break it is—for example, “Meal Break 30 Min” or “Paid Rest Break 10 Min”—so employees and managers can easily identify it.

content: UZIO supports two main break categories: Meal and Rest. Break Category groups similar breaks under a common type so that reporting and compliance logic can distinguish, for example, unpaid meal breaks from shorter paid rest breaks. You assign each Break Rule to a category, which helps drive how the system interprets compliance, premiums, and state-specific rules.

content: Break Type describes how the break is treated from a time and pay perspective. Common distinctions include paid vs unpaid breaks, and whether the break is on the clock (paid rest break) or off the clock (unpaid meal break). Setting the Break Type ensures that when employees punch out and back in for breaks, UZIO correctly adjusts working time and, where applicable, distinguishes breaks that should not reduce paid hours.

content: Break Duration defines the planned length of the break—for example, a 30-minute meal break or a 10-minute rest break. This configured duration is used when evaluating whether a break was short, too long, or compliant. It also informs guardrails such as auto-end of breaks or notifications. For unpaid breaks, duration may also affect how much working time is subtracted from the shift when employees take their break.

content:
Break Eligibility Window defines when, relative to the start of work or a shift, an employee becomes eligible (or required) to take a particular break. For example, you can specify that an employee becomes eligible for a first meal break after 5 hours of work. UZIO then uses this threshold to evaluate when the break should be taken for compliance and to decide when to flag a missed break or auto-deduct a break if not taken.
You may also define repeating windows (for example, a second rest break every additional few hours) using a “repeat break for every __ hours and __ minutes” configuration. The eligibility window settings control when the system starts checking for missed or short breaks and are critical for state-specific rules like California meal and rest break laws.

content: The Resolving Missed Breaks configuration determines how UZIO should handle situations where an employee does not take a required break within the defined eligibility window. In this section, you choose whether the system should automatically insert a missed break entry, simply flag a missed break for manager review, or rely on break attestations and manual manager actions to resolve exceptions. These settings help ensure that missed breaks are handled consistently for payroll, compliance, and audit purposes.

content:
Auto Deduct/Flag controls the automatic action UZIO takes when a break is not taken within its eligible window. You can choose among options such as:
- Deduct Missing Break: The system automatically inserts a deduction (representing a missed or auto-applied break) into the time record, which adjusts worked time and payroll totals.
- Flag Missing Break: The system does not change the recorded working time but flags the entry as having a missed break for managers to review.
This setting allows you to decide whether missed breaks should automatically reduce hours or simply be highlighted as compliance exceptions.

content:
The Deduct/Flag Missing Break at setting specifies the exact point in time—relative to break eligibility—when UZIO should apply the selected auto-deduct or flag action. For example, you might configure the system to treat a break as missed if it has not started by a certain number of hours after the eligibility threshold. When that time passes without a break being recorded, UZIO either inserts a missed break deduction or flags the entry, according to your Auto Deduct/Flag configuration.
This allows you to reflect nuanced rules where breaks must be taken not only within a broad window but also by a particular cutoff point, supporting precise compliance with regulations and your internal policies.

content:
Break Premium settings govern how UZIO calculates extra pay when break rules are violated, such as when a required break is missed or taken late. Depending on the jurisdiction and company policy, this may involve adding an extra hour of premium pay or applying another premium calculation when a break is not provided as required.
In this section, you define when premiums should be triggered and how they should be calculated. The premium amounts are then reflected in time reports and can be synced to payroll as separate earnings, helping ensure employees receive required penalties or premiums for non-compliant break situations.

content:
Break Attestation allows employees to confirm whether they took their required breaks and whether those breaks were compliant (for example, taken on time and for the full duration). After clocking out, or at specific times, employees may be prompted to attest that they received all required meal and rest breaks, or to indicate if any were missed or interrupted.
These attestations are stored with the time entries and can be used in reporting or audits to show employees’ acknowledgment of their break status. They are especially important in jurisdictions where employers must demonstrate that employees were given the opportunity to take legally required breaks.

content: Break Guardrails are protective controls that govern how employees can start, end, or extend breaks. They define system behavior for preventing early break start, preventing early break end, automatically ending breaks when their configured duration is reached, and identifying short or long breaks. These settings help ensure that breaks follow your policy and that exceptions such as too-short or excessively long breaks are correctly captured for review.

If an employee attempts to start a break too early, UZIO can block the action or warn the user, depending on configuration. This helps prevent employees from taking breaks prematurely and ensures that required breaks are taken within appropriate windows for compliance and operational needs.

If an employee attempts to end their break too soon, UZIO can either block the action or flag the entry, ensuring that required break lengths are honored. This is particularly important for compliance with laws that require full meal or rest break durations.

content: The Automatically end break when duration ends guardrail instructs UZIO to auto-end an employee’s break once the configured break duration has been reached. If the employee does not manually punch back in, the system records the break end at the expected time. This prevents breaks from running indefinitely due to forgotten punch-ins and keeps recorded break lengths aligned with policy.

For example, you might specify a tolerance window and then decide whether short breaks should be flagged for review, treated as missed breaks, or impact break premiums. These can include notifications when a break becomes due, reminders to start or end breaks, and alerts when a break is missed or taken outside the allowed window. content: Employers can edit Break Rules when break policies change or corrections are needed. To edit a rule, go to Time Tracking Settings, open the Breaks tab, locate the specific Break Rule, and click Edit in the Actions menu. content: To delete a Break Rule, open Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation, go to the Breaks tab, locate the rule you want to remove, and click Delete in the Actions menu. When you confirm deletion, the rule is removed from active use and unassigned from all employees. Existing time entries and historical records that were already evaluated using the rule remain as they were; UZIO does not retroactively change time entries when a Break Rule is deleted. Deletion is primarily used when a policy is no longer applicable and you want to prevent the rule from being used going forward.

content: UZIO’s geofencing feature lets employers define a virtual boundary around each work location so that the system can detect whether employees are clocking in and out inside or outside the allowed area. From Time Tracking Settings > Geofence, the admin selects a location, opens its Actions menu, and edits the address. They can enable geofence and choose a shape (typically circular or polygon) using a map with a draggable pin. The radius or area is adjusted so that the geofence covers the physical worksite. Employers can choose to either block punches outside the geofence (hard restriction) or allow them but flag those entries for review. This improves data accuracy, prevents off-site clocking, and provides a clean audit trail for location-based compliance. Geofences are configured per location, and once saved, they apply to any time capture mode (mobile, kiosk, or web) where geofence enforcement is turned on.
image_descriptions: Settings screen for Time Tracking > Geofence tab showing a table of work locations in rows with columns for location name, address, geofence status, and an Actions dropdown. One row is expanded or in edit mode, opening a modal with a map, a pin marking the address, and controls to select Circular or Polygon geofence and a radius slider.
Map view focused on a single worksite where a circular shaded region around the pin indicates the geofence boundary, with drag handles to adjust the radius.
generated_questions: How do I configure a geofence around a work location so employees can only clock in when they are on site?

section_title: Schedule Settings within Time Tracking Setup
content: Schedule Settings become available once the Scheduling module is enabled alongside Time Tracking. During the guided configuration flow, employers open Time Tracking Settings and go to the Schedule area to define how scheduling behaves company-wide. Typical configurations include how and when employees are notified about shifts (on publish, before the start time, and before the end time), whether early or late clock windows are enforced, and various defaults for views and behavior in the scheduler. These settings standardize the scheduling experience across locations and teams. Once saved, the preferences apply to all future schedules, and managers creating or managing shifts benefit from consistent notification rules and clocking windows that reflect company policy and local labor requirements.
image_descriptions: Schedule settings panel under Time Tracking Settings with toggles and numeric inputs for options like 'Notify employees when schedule is published', 'Send reminder X minutes before shift start', 'Send reminder Y minutes before shift end', and an early/late clock-in threshold field.
Side-by-side preview showing how employee shift notifications will appear, with an example email template or push notification message referencing a specific shift time.
generated_questions: Where do I configure company-wide schedule notification rules in UZIO?
How can I control how early employees are reminded about upcoming shifts?
Do schedule settings in Time Tracking apply across all locations and employees or just one team?

content: Time Clocks and General Settings define how employees actually record time and how those entries are governed. From Time Tracking Settings, employers choose which time capture modes to enable—Web, Mobile, and/or Kiosk—and, for each mode, configure relevant options. For Web, they determine whether web punching is allowed; for Mobile, they can enforce geofence checks at the moment of punch; for Kiosk, they define Kiosk Name, Login Method (PIN, employee ID, or both), Photo Security (require photo at clock in/out or at intervals), an Activation Code to link a physical device to the company, and consent language informing employees about photo capture. In the same area, General Settings control whether employees can add, edit, or delete their own entries, and whether such manual changes require manager approval. Admins can require notes when time is changed, choose whether employees can view their time history, pick the time display format (12-hour or 24-hour), set a rule to flag missing clock-outs after X hours, and configure long-running entry notifications (first and second reminders) as well as reminders for missed time attestation. By clicking Save and Publish, these rules are applied globally so that time tracking behavior is consistent and auditable.
image_descriptions: A Time Clocks configuration screen with three sections labeled Web, Mobile, and Kiosk, each with toggles such as 'Enable web clocking', 'Enforce geofence on mobile', and fields for Kiosk Name, Login Method dropdown, Photo Security checkbox, and Activation Code textbox.

General Settings panel listing options like 'Allow employees to add/edit/delete time', 'Require manager approval for manual entries', 'Require notes on changes', 'Show time history to employees', 'Time display format (12h/24h)', 'Flag missing clock-out after X hours', and 'Notify for long-running entries' with corresponding toggles and numeric fields.

What general settings can I configure to control whether employees can edit their own time entries?
