section_title: Roles and Permissions for Time Tracking
content: UZIO uses role-based permissions to control which employer users can configure Time Tracking or manage employee timesheets. From Manage Users, an Employer Admin opens a role and adjusts two key permission areas. Under Company Access, the 'Schedule & Time Tracking' permission determines whether a user can view or edit company-level Time Tracking settings. No Access means they cannot open configuration pages; View Only lets them see settings like employees enabled for Time Tracking, overtime and break rules, schedules, geofences, and other options without changing them; Full Access allows them to add employees, configure overtime and break rules, manage schedules, and adjust geofences and other time tracking settings. Under Employee Access, the 'Employee Timesheet' permission governs visibility and control over employees’ timesheets. No Access hides employees from the Employees’ Timesheet page, View Only allows viewing but not editing or approving, and Full Access grants the ability to modify entries and approve timesheets. These permissions ensure that only appropriate users can make policy or timesheet changes while others stay limited to viewing data or personal self-service.
image_descriptions: Role configuration screen showing tabs for Company Access and Employee Access. Under Company Access, a row labeled 'Schedule & Time Tracking' has a dropdown with options: No Access, View Only, Full Access. Under Employee Access, a row labeled 'Employee Timesheet' shows the same three-level dropdown.
A Manage Users listing page with roles such as Employer Admin, Payroll Admin, HR Manager, and icons or links to edit each role's access to Time Tracking and Scheduling.
generated_questions: How can I give a manager permission to approve employee timesheets without letting them change Time Tracking settings?
What is the difference between Company Access and Employee Access for Time Tracking roles?
Where do I configure who can manage schedules, overtime rules, and break rules in UZIO?

content: An employee can only use UZIO Time Tracking if they are active and explicitly added to Time Tracking. From Time Tracking Settings > Employees, admins click 'Select Employees' to see a list of active employees who are not yet enabled for time tracking, then select and save. There is a prerequisite that each employee’s pay group must have an active payroll calendar; if not, the system blocks the assignment and shows an error message. Newly hired employees added outside the normal prospective or onboarding flow must also be added here manually. Prospective employees can be pre-assigned to Time Tracking during self-onboarding on the Time Tools page by selecting the employee and choosing their overtime and break rules; they cannot record time until their status becomes Active, but the configuration is ready in advance. To stop someone from tracking time, the admin goes back to Time Tracking Settings > Employees, finds them in the Selected Employees list, and chooses 'Remove Employee' from the Actions menu, which instantly prevents clock in/out and break usage for that person. Separate actions allow changing the assigned Overtime Rule (one per employee) and Break Rules (multiple per employee) at any time from the same Employees tab.
image_descriptions: Employees tab in Time Tracking Settings showing two sections: 'Select Employees' button opening a modal listing active employees not yet in Time Tracking, and a 'Selected Employees' table listing current time-tracking employees with columns for name, pay group, overtime rule, break rules, and an Actions menu.
Self-onboarding Time Tools page where a new hire record shows checkboxes or dropdowns to enable Time Tracking and assign an overtime rule and break rules before the employee becomes active.

section_title: Employee Time Tracking on Web – Clocking and Breaks
content: On the web, employees access Time Tracking from the employee portal to clock in and out, manage breaks, and interact with their timesheets. From the Time Tracking page, the main widget shows their current status (clocked in or out), the clock-in/out buttons, and available break types. To start work, the employee clicks Clock In; the system records the start time and, if configured, applies geofence checks and any schedule rules. To end the work segment, they click Clock Out, which closes the time entry. During a shift, employees can initiate a break by clicking Break In and choosing the correct break type (e.g., Meal, Rest) configured in Break Rules; when they are ready to resume, they click Break Out. Break policies, eligibility windows, and guardrails (like preventing early starts or early ends) are enforced in the background. The web experience is designed to be simple and clear, giving employees a real-time view of their current status and helping them take breaks according to company policy and statutory requirements.
image_descriptions: Employee web dashboard showing a Time Tracking card with a prominent button labeled 'Clock In' or 'Clock Out', a secondary button group for 'Break In' and 'Break Out', and a status line reading 'You are currently clocked in since 09:02 AM' along with today’s total hours.
Drop-down or modal listing available break types such as 'Meal Break - 30 minutes (Unpaid)' and 'Rest Break - 10 minutes (Paid)' with a brief description of each break and a Start button.
generated_questions: How does an employee clock in and out using the UZIO web portal?
What is the process for starting and ending a meal or rest break on the web?
How does UZIO enforce break rules and guardrails while employees use Time Tracking on a browser?

content: Beyond real-time clocking, employees can open and manage their timesheet for a given pay period in the web portal. From Time Tracking, they navigate to the timesheet, select the appropriate date range, and see a grid of daily entries with columns such as Date, Time In, Time Out, Breaks, Total Hours, and Notes. Depending on employer settings, employees can add a time entry manually (for missed punches), edit an existing entry (adjusting in/out times), or delete an entry that was created in error. When making changes, the system may require them to provide a note explaining the modification. A Clock Out action from within the timesheet screen closes any running entry. Employees can add notes to specific days to document exceptions or clarify special situations and can view History to see an audit trail of changes. Time Attestation may be enabled so that employees attest to the accuracy of each entry or of the entire timesheet using options such as Attest Time Entry or Attest All at the end of the period, which locks in their confirmation for compliance.
image_descriptions: Timesheet grid for an employee showing rows per day and columns for Time In, Time Out, Breaks, Total Hours, and a Notes icon. Above the grid are controls to select the pay period, and buttons like 'Add Time', 'History', and 'Attest All'.
Modal dialog for adding or editing a time entry with fields for Date, Time In, Time Out, Breaks, Job or Project (optional), and a free-text Notes field plus Save/Cancel buttons.
generated_questions: How can employees manually add or edit time entries on their UZIO timesheet?
What information is shown in the timesheet grid for each day in a pay period?
How do employees attest that their timesheet is accurate, and what does the 'Attest All' option do?

section_title: Employee Time Tracking on Mobile – Clocking and Breaks
content: In the UZIO mobile app, employees can clock in, clock out, and manage breaks from their phones. After logging in, they tap the Time or Time Tracking section, which shows their current status and a large primary button to start or end their shift. When they tap Clock In, the app records the start time and, if enabled, performs a geofence check against the configured work location boundary. To initiate a break, they tap Break In and select the configured break type; to resume work, they tap Break Out. Mobile workflows also surface break notifications—such as reminders to start or end a break—via push, SMS, or email as defined by the employer. The interface is optimized for quick actions, with clear labels and status indicators, so employees in the field or on the road can comply with timekeeping and break policies without needing a desktop.
image_descriptions: Mobile screen showing a circular status indicator with text 'You are clocked out' and a large primary button labeled 'Clock In', plus additional buttons or menu options for 'Break In', 'Break Out', and a link to 'View Timesheet'.
Push notification banner on a phone reading something like 'Meal Break is about to start in 10 minutes' or 'End your Meal Break in 10 minutes and resume your shift', coming from the UZIO app.
generated_questions: How do employees clock in and out using the UZIO mobile app?

section_title: Missed Break Handling and Break Premium Calculations
content: UZIO provides detailed controls for handling missed, short, and long breaks and for awarding break premiums. Break Eligibility Windows define when a break becomes due (first window and repeating windows), and the Resolving Missed Breaks settings determine what happens if the employee doesn’t take the break within that window. Admins can choose Auto Deduct Missing Break (the system inserts a break of the configured duration into the time entry) or Flag Missing Break (no change to hours, but a missed break event is recorded for review). A 'Deduct/Flag Missing Break at' setting controls where in the shift the missed break is placed—at the start, middle, end of the window, or at a custom offset. The Break Premium option lets employers award a premium of X hours and Y minutes for each missed break; these premium hours are capped (for example, 1 hour maximum per break category per entry) and are sent to payroll under a designated earning code. Break Attestation can be required so that, at clock-out, the employee must choose whether they took the break, were prevented by work from taking it, or chose not to take it, with notes and policy-driven premiums applied accordingly. Together, these controls create a consistent, auditable framework for handling missed breaks and ensuring wage-and-hour compliance.
image_descriptions: Break Rule configuration form showing sections for 'Resolving Missed Breaks' with radio buttons for 'Deduct Missing Break' and 'Flag Missing Break', a dropdown for 'Deduct/Flag Missing Break at' with options (Start, Middle, End, Custom), and numeric fields for 'Premium hours' with a note about maximum capping.

Break Attestation prompt displayed at clock-out with three selectable statements: 'Yes, I took this break', 'No, I was prevented by work from taking this break', and 'I had the opportunity, but I freely chose not to take this break', plus an optional comments field.
generated_questions: What options does UZIO provide for handling missed breaks in employee time entries?

content: Time Entry Exceptions highlight timekeeping issues that need attention before approval and payroll. UZIO categorizes exceptions such as Missing Clock Out, Running Time Entry, Manager Approval Pending for Manually Added Entries, Manager Approval Pending for Manually Edited Entries, Missed Breaks, Short Breaks, and Long Breaks. A Missing Clock Out occurs when the employee fails to end an entry within the configured maximum duration from start; the system flags it for review and, depending on settings, can trigger notifications. A Running Time Entry indicates an open entry that continues accruing hours beyond expected limits. Manually added or edited entries can be configured to require manager approval, generating 'Manager Approval Pending' exceptions until reviewed. Missed, short, and long breaks are detected based on break duration and guardrail thresholds and are flagged accordingly. Employers and managers use the exceptions list on the Employees’ Timesheet page to drill in, correct entries, add notes, or acknowledge missed breaks so that timesheets are clean and compliant before approval and syncing to payroll.
image_descriptions: Exceptions panel on the Employees’ Timesheet screen listing categories such as Missing Clock Out, Running Time Entry, Manager Approval Pending (Added), Manager Approval Pending (Edited), Missed Breaks, Short Breaks, and Long Breaks, each with a count of affected employees and links to view details.
Detailed exception view for an employee showing a row with date, exception type (e.g., 'Missing Clock Out'), original time, status, and action buttons like 'Edit', 'Acknowledge', or 'Resolve'.
generated_questions: What types of time entry exceptions does UZIO detect and flag for managers?

content: The Timesheet Approval section explains how employer users and managers review and finalize employee timesheets at the end of a period (typically daily, weekly, or per pay period). Managers go to the Employee Timesheet page, filter by pay period, location, or team, and review each employee’s hours, breaks, overtime, exceptions, and attestations. The grid highlights issues such as missing clock-outs, missed breaks, long-running entries, or items pending manager approval (for manually added or edited time). Managers can drill into an employee’s timesheet, review individual entries, notes, photos (if Photo Security is enabled), and attestations before approving. Once satisfied, they can approve a single employee’s timesheet or use bulk actions to approve multiple employees at once. After approval, the timesheet becomes locked for that period (based on your settings), and changes may require additional approval. Approved timesheets form the source of truth for payroll hours.
image_descriptions: Screenshot of the Employee Timesheet page showing a table of employees, pay periods, total hours, status (Approved/Pending), and icons indicating exceptions and notes. Action buttons such as View Timesheet and Approve appear on the right.

Detail view of an individual employee’s timesheet with a weekly calendar grid. Each day row displays time entries, break segments, total hours, overtime, and status badges. A toolbar at the top includes options like Approve, Reject, and Export.
generated_questions: How does a manager review and approve employee timesheets in UZIO?

content: The Syncing Hours to Payroll section describes how approved time tracking data flows into UZIO Payroll. After timesheets are approved for a pay period, an employer user with payroll access can open the payroll run and use an option such as Sync Time or Import Hours from Time Tracking. The system fetches all approved hours and premiums (regular, overtime, double overtime, break premiums, and other earnings mapped to specific earning codes) and populates the payroll input grid. Only approved entries are included; pending or unapproved changes remain excluded to protect payroll accuracy. The section also explains that if timesheets are edited after a sync, the user may need to re-sync or manually adjust payroll, depending on configuration. Mapping between time categories (regular, OT, DOT, premiums) and payroll earning codes is maintained at the configuration level, ensuring consistent postings to each pay item. The sync process helps eliminate duplicate data entry and reduces payroll errors.
image_descriptions: Payroll run screen showing a banner that indicates 'Time Tracking sync available' with a button labeled 'Import Time' or 'Sync Hours.' Below is a grid listing employees, with Regular, OT, and Premium columns filled after sync.
Configuration dialog showing mappings between time tracking categories (Regular Hours, OT Hours, DOT Hours, Break Premium) and payroll earning codes (e.g., REG, OT1.5, OT2.0, BRKP).
generated_questions: How do approved timesheet hours get transferred into UZIO Payroll?

content: The Time Entry History section explains how UZIO keeps an audit trail for each time entry. For every clock in/out, break in/out, or manual add/edit/delete, the system stores who performed the action (employee, manager, system), when it occurred, and what fields changed (start time, end time, duration, break type, notes, premiums, etc.). Users with appropriate permissions can open a time entry and see a History tab or panel that lists all prior versions and actions in chronological order. This helps answer questions like who changed a shift, why a clock-out was adjusted, or when a missed break was acknowledged. Notes required by configuration (for manual modifications) are also visible in the history view. The history is read-only and is retained for compliance, audit, and payroll dispute resolution.
image_descriptions: Time entry detail panel with a History tab showing a vertical timeline. Each row displays the date/time of change, user name, action (Created, Edited, Deleted, Auto-adjusted), and a summary of what changed.
Example history record highlighting that a manager changed a clock-out time, including old and new values and the note provided.

content: The Reports section introduces the reporting capabilities of UZIO Time Tracking. It explains that employer users with reporting permissions can run different reports to analyze time data: Time Entries Report, Daily Hours Worked Report, and Payroll Hours Summary Report. These reports can be filtered by date range, pay period, location, department, job title, or employee. The section describes that reports can be previewed on screen and exported to formats like Excel or CSV for deeper analysis or for sharing with other stakeholders. It also notes that the data shown respects role-based access: a manager only sees employees they are allowed to view. The section emphasizes using reports for compliance checks, labor cost visibility, and verifying hours before payroll.
image_descriptions: Reports landing page listing available reports: Time Entries Report, Daily Hours Worked Report, and Payroll Hours Summary Report. Each report has a brief description and a 'Run Report' button.
Filter panel for a report showing date range pickers, pay period selector, location dropdown, department dropdown, and employee search field.

content: The Time Entries Report provides a detailed, row-level view of all time entries within a selected period. Each row typically includes employee details (name, ID), date, clock-in and clock-out times, total hours, regular hours, overtime hours, double overtime hours, break segments, break types, and any exceptions or notes. Filters allow users to narrow results by employee, team, location, job, or exception type (e.g., missed break, missing clock-out). The report is ideal for auditing specific days or verifying that particular employees worked certain hours. It can also show how many entries were created manually versus by clock actions. Exported data can be used for external analysis, compliance audits, or to investigate disputes.
image_descriptions: Table-style report listing one row per time entry with columns for Employee Name, Date, Start Time, End Time, Total Hours, OT Hours, DOT Hours, Breaks, Exception Flags, and Notes.

content: The Daily Hours Worked Report summarizes hours by employee and day instead of by individual entry. For each date and employee, the report aggregates total hours, regular hours, overtime, double overtime, and possibly break premium hours. This gives a concise daily view of labor, making it easier to check compliance with daily overtime or daily break rules. The section explains that the report can be filtered by date range, location, department, and other attributes. It is commonly used by supervisors to quickly see who worked which days, identify under-scheduled or over-scheduled staff, and verify that daily OT aligns with policy and laws. The report can be exported for payroll support or external analysis.
image_descriptions: Report grid showing columns for Date, Employee Name, Total Hours, Regular Hours, OT Hours, DOT Hours, Premium Hours, and possibly Break Exceptions.
Chart-style visualization summarizing total daily hours per location or department over a selected week.

content: The Payroll Hours Summary Report aggregates hours at a pay-period level to support payroll processing. For each employee and pay period, it shows total paid hours grouped by category: regular, overtime, double overtime, break premiums, and other configured categories. The report often aligns directly with how data is synced into payroll, making it a bridge between time tracking and pay calculations. The section explains that users can compare this summary to payroll outputs to validate that the correct hours and earnings have been processed. Filters allow narrowing by pay group, location, or other attributes. Exporting this report provides a clear audit trail of the hours that should drive payroll for a given period.

content: The Administrative Tools section introduces advanced options for power users and administrators, including bulk import of time entries, mandatory row order for imports, and manual modifications management. It explains that these tools are useful when migrating from another system, correcting large data sets, or adjusting historical records. The section clarifies that the ability to use these tools is controlled by role-based permissions to avoid unauthorized changes. It also highlights that all changes made via admin tools still respect audit trails, requiring notes where configured and sending items through manager approval workflows if necessary.
image_descriptions: Administrative Tools page within Time Tracking settings showing links or tabs for Bulk Import Time Entries, Manual Modifications, and configuration settings.
Warning banner indicating that bulk operations affect multiple records and should be used carefully.

content: The Bulk Import Time Entries section explains how administrators can upload a file to create or update many time entries at once. UZIO provides a specific template format (often CSV or Excel) that includes required columns such as Employee Identifier, Date, Start Time, End Time or Duration, Break Codes, and earning categories. The section guides users to download the template, populate it with data, validate mandatory fields, and then upload it through the Time Tracking interface. Upon upload, the system validates each row for correct employee mapping, date format, overlapping entries, and break rules. Errors are flagged with messages so the user can correct and re-upload. Successfully imported entries appear in employees’ timesheets and may require manager approval based on configuration. Bulk import is particularly useful for backfilling historical data or loading entries from another system.
image_descriptions: Upload dialog for Bulk Import Time Entries with options to download a sample template, choose a file, and start the import. A progress indicator shows the status of the import.
Error review screen listing rows that failed validation, including the row number, employee, date, and a message such as 'Invalid Employee ID' or 'Overlapping entry.'

content: This section describes the mandatory row order and structure that must be followed in the bulk import template. It explains that specific columns must appear in a defined sequence, such as Employee Identifier, Date, Time Entry Type (e.g., Clock, Duration), Start Time, End Time or Duration, Break Code, Job or Department, and optional fields like Notes. Some columns may be required for all rows (like employee and date), while others are conditional depending on the type of record. The system expects the header names to match exactly and may reject files with missing or misordered columns. The section typically provides a table describing each column, data type, and whether it is required. Following this mandatory order ensures that the import engine can correctly interpret each row.
image_descriptions: Sample import template displayed in a spreadsheet with header row showing the required column order (Employee ID, Date, Type, Start Time, End Time, etc.). Required columns are highlighted.
Documentation table listing each column name, description, data type, and whether it is mandatory or optional.

section_title: Manual Modifications in the Time Entries and Approval – Overview
content: This section explains how manual modifications to time entries are handled in UZIO and how approval workflows apply to those changes. Employees and managers can add, edit, or delete time entries within allowed permissions. When an employee makes a manual change, the system can require a reason/note and then mark the entry as 'Pending Manager Approval.' Managers review pending changes, accept or reject them, and the system tracks all actions in the time entry history. The section emphasizes that manual modifications are designed to correct exceptions (like missed clock-ins) without compromising auditability or compliance. Configuration options let employers decide if employee changes are auto-approved or always require manager review.
image_descriptions: Timesheet view with a banner indicating that some entries are pending manager approval. Icons next to entries show a 'Pending' status for manual additions or edits.
Manager review dialog showing details of a modified entry, original values, new values, the employee’s note, and buttons to Approve or Reject.

content: The 'Adding a Time Entry' section describes how users can add new entries to a timesheet when clocking actions were missed or when duration-based tracking is used. From their timesheet, an employee or manager clicks an Add Time or Add Entry button and selects the date, start time, end time, and any associated details such as job, department, or notes. The system checks for overlaps with existing entries and validates against rules like maximum shift length or required breaks. If the configuration requires it, an employee’s manually added entry is flagged for manager approval. The section reminds users to add accurate notes explaining why an entry is being created after the fact, which supports audits and approvals.
image_descriptions: Add Time Entry form with fields for Date, Start Time, End Time or Duration, Job, Location, and Notes, plus Save and Cancel buttons.
Timesheet grid showing a newly added time block highlighted with a 'Pending' badge to indicate it is awaiting manager approval.

section_title: Adding Time Entry by Clock In/Out
content: This subsection explains how a time entry can be created by specifying clock-in and clock-out timestamps rather than only a duration. Users enter the actual start and end times of a shift or segment, and the system calculates the duration automatically. This is useful when replicating what a physical time clock would have captured. The section clarifies that breaks can either be embedded as separate break entries or the user can record only the work segment if breaks were handled elsewhere. The system still validates overlaps and maximum shift length and can apply overtime rules based on total hours. Any manual clock-in/out entries may be subject to manager approval based on settings.

content: This subsection covers adding time entries when only the total duration is known. Instead of providing an exact start and end time, the user selects a date and enters the number of hours worked (e.g., 5.5 hours). content: The 'Editing a Time Entry' section describes how users can correct existing entries when mistakes occur. With appropriate permissions, a user opens their timesheet, selects a specific entry, and clicks Edit. They can adjust start and end times, duration, break associations, job or department, and notes. UZIO revalidates overlaps, shift length, break eligibility, and overtime calculations after the edit. If the configuration requires notes on modification, the system prompts the user to explain the change. Edits made by employees can be automatically approved or marked as 'Pending Manager Approval' based on company settings. All edits are captured in the time entry history for audit purposes.

The system may require a confirmation step and a note describing why the entry is being removed. Deleting an entry can adjust daily and weekly totals, including overtime and premiums, so UZIO recalculates affected days accordingly. If the setting is enabled, deletions by employees may be flagged for manager approval or at least recorded in the history. The actual deletion is captured as an audit event in the time entry history, including who performed it and when, ensuring transparency.

content: This subsection clarifies the workflow when employees are allowed to modify their own time entries. When the setting 'Manager approval for employee modifications' is enabled, any manual add, edit, or delete performed by an employee marks the entry as pending approval. Managers see a dedicated list or indicators on timesheets for entries awaiting their decision. They can open each pending change, review the original and updated values, read the employee’s notes, and then approve or reject. Approving adopts the new values into the timesheet; rejecting reverts to the original state or removes the proposed entry. This process ensures accurate records while preserving employee self-service capabilities. All decisions are stored in the time entry history.

content: The Time Attestation section describes how employers can require employees to confirm the accuracy of their time entries. In configuration, an employer can enable time attestation and define when the attestation prompt appears (for example, at clock-out, at the end of each day, or when submitting a timesheet for a pay period). The employer also defines the attestation statement text, such as confirming that all hours worked have been recorded accurately, breaks were taken according to policy, and no off-the-clock work occurred. The section explains how this setting interacts with reminders for missed attestations and how it supports compliance and audit requirements.

When employees clock out, complete a day, or submit a timesheet (depending on configuration), they see an attestation prompt. They must review the statement—confirming that hours recorded are accurate, breaks were taken or reported, and all time worked is captured—and then click a button or check a box to attest. The system records the attestation decision, timestamp, and user in the time entry or timesheet history. If an employee notices an error, they can cancel, fix their entries, and then attest again. Attestation records serve as evidence in compliance audits or disputes.

section_title: Missed Time Attestation Notification – Daily and Per Pay Period
content: This subsection explains how UZIO reminds employees or managers when required attestations are not completed. For daily notifications, the system checks at the configured time whether employees have attested to their daily entries. If not, it sends a reminder via email, SMS, or push notification, depending on employer settings. For per pay period notifications, the system checks at the close of a pay period whether timecards remain un-attested and sends reminders accordingly. The settings allow admins to choose channels, timing, and recipients (employee, manager, or both). These reminders help ensure that all required attestations are completed before payroll is processed.

section_title: Time Kiosk Guide – What the Time Kiosk Offers
content: The Time Kiosk Guide introduces UZIO’s dedicated kiosk mode for capturing time at shared devices in workplaces such as warehouses, retail stores, and offices. It explains that the kiosk allows multiple employees to clock in/out and take breaks from a single device using secure login methods like PIN or Face Unlock. The kiosk supports Photo Security so that each punch can be accompanied by a snapshot for verification. The section highlights that kiosk usage is ideal for locations where employees do not have personal devices or where a central physical clocking station is needed. It also notes that kiosk entries integrate seamlessly with the same timesheets, overtime rules, and break policies used by mobile and web.

Features commonly include multi-employee support from a single device, secure login via PIN or Face Unlock, Photo Security during punches, simple clock in/out and break workflows, offline mode support (if enabled), and automatic sync to the cloud once connectivity is available. section_title: For Employer Administrators: Setting up the Time Kiosk
content: This section explains the steps employer administrators must follow to set up a new kiosk. In Time Tracking settings, they navigate to the Time Clocks tab, add a new kiosk, and provide a Kiosk Name, choose the login method (PIN or Face Unlock/PIN), and enable Photo Security if desired. The system generates or expects an Activation Code, which is entered on the physical device by visiting the kiosk URL (e.g., kiosk.uzio.com). Once the code is entered, the device is linked to that kiosk record. Administrators must also accept biometric consent terms if face recognition or photo capture is used. After activation, employees added to time tracking receive PINs via email. The section may describe how to deactivate or reassign a kiosk to another device and how to control which employees can use the kiosk.

content: This section describes the employee experience at the kiosk. To use the kiosk, an employee enters their PIN or uses Face Unlock, then sees options to Clock In, Clock Out, Start Break, or End Break, depending on their current status. If Photo Security is enabled, the kiosk captures a photo when they punch. The screen clearly shows their name, current time, and confirmation messages such as 'You are now clocked in.' Break flows respect configured break rules, including eligibility windows and guardrails. Administrators can control which locations and kiosks specific employees can use. Photo Security can be turned on to ensure that a photo is taken with each clock in/out for identity verification. Face Unlock requires employees to enroll their facial data according to the system’s biometric policy. section_title: Using Time Tracking in Offline Mode – Overview and Enabling
content: The Offline Mode section explains how UZIO Time Tracking continues to function when network connectivity is temporarily unavailable. When offline mode is enabled in settings, mobile apps and kiosks can still capture clock in/out and break actions even if they cannot immediately reach the server. The system securely stores these punches locally on the device, tagging them as pending sync. The section describes how an administrator can enable offline mode, typically via a toggle in Time Tracking settings, and may highlight that offline operation is recommended for locations with unstable connectivity. It also notes that some actions may be restricted while offline to reduce conflict risk.

section_title: Offline Mode – Allowed Actions, Sync Behavior, and Conflict Handling (Edit / Discard)
content: This subsection details what employees can and cannot do while offline, how data sync works, and how conflicts are resolved. While offline, employees can generally clock in, clock out, and record breaks; in some configurations they may be able to view limited historical entries cached on the device. Actions that require real-time validation (like viewing full report data or heavy configuration changes) may be blocked until connectivity returns. When the device reconnects, it sends all locally stored punches to the server. If no conflicts exist, entries are inserted as if they were recorded in real time, using the original timestamps. If conflicts are detected—such as overlapping entries created from another device or manager edits made while the device was offline—the system flags them for review. Administrators or managers may see options to Edit (adjust details to resolve the conflict) or Discard (ignore the offline version and keep the server state). The history log notes that the entry originated from offline mode and documents how the conflict was resolved.

section_title: Weighted vs Blended Overtime – Are They the Same?
content: This section clarifies the terminology around blended and weighted overtime. It explains that the term “blended overtime” is often used interchangeably with “weighted” or “weighted average overtime rate.” In all cases, the concept refers to calculating overtime based on a single averaged regular rate that accounts for multiple different hourly rates worked in the same workweek. Rather than using one job’s base rate, the system determines a combined regular rate from total straight-time earnings across all jobs and hours, and uses that blended rate to calculate overtime premiums. The section emphasizes that although different terms are used, they all describe the same fundamental compliance requirement when employees work at more than one pay rate.
image_descriptions: A simple comparison table with two columns: one titled 'Term' listing 'Blended rate', 'Weighted overtime', 'Weighted average overtime', and the other titled 'Meaning' stating 'All refer to overtime calculated from a weighted average of multiple pay rates in a week.'
generated_questions: Are blended overtime rates and weighted overtime rates different concepts or the same thing?
Why do people use terms like blended, weighted, or weighted-average overtime interchangeably?
In what situations do I need to worry about blended or weighted overtime rates instead of a single base rate?

section_title: How to Calculate a Blended (Weighted Average) Overtime Rate
content: This section walks through a step-by-step example of calculating blended overtime when an employee works two different jobs at different hourly rates in the same week. In the example, an employee named David works 30 hours as a Driver at $10/hour and 20 hours as a Cleaner at $20/hour, for a total of 50 hours, including 5 overtime hours. Step 1 is to calculate total straight-time wages by multiplying hours for each job by its rate and summing the results: (30 × $10) + (20 × $20) = $700. Step 2 is to divide the total straight-time wages by total hours worked (regular + OT + DOT) to get the blended regular rate: $700 ÷ 50 = $14/hour. Step 3 is to calculate the overtime premium: the additional half-time amount is half of the blended rate ($7). Each job’s blended overtime rate becomes its base hourly rate plus $7 (for example, Driver OT = $17/hour, Cleaner OT = $27/hour). The same idea applies for double time, using twice the blended regular rate to determine the double-time premium added to each base rate. UZIO uses this approach to properly allocate overtime and double-time wages across all jobs worked in the week.
image_descriptions: An example calculation table with rows for 'Driver' and 'Cleaner' showing Hours (30 and 20), Rate ($10 and $20), and Straight Wages ($300 and $400) with a Total row showing 50 hours and $700 wages.
A small formula box showing: Step 1 – Total wages = $700; Step 2 – Blended rate = $700 ÷ 50 = $14; Step 3 – OT premium = $14 ÷ 2 = $7; Driver OT = $10 + $7 = $17; Cleaner OT = $20 + $7 = $27.

section_title: Workplace Setup: Best Practices for Kiosk Placement
content: This section outlines best practices for physically placing the Time Kiosk in the workplace. It recommends choosing a convenient, easily accessible location, such as near the main entrance or a common area, so employees can quickly clock in and out without creating bottlenecks. Security is emphasized: the device should be physically secured using a stand, mounts, and locks to prevent theft or tampering. The section notes that orientation matters—if the tablet’s camera is along the shorter or longer edge, the kiosk should be used in portrait or landscape orientation accordingly so that photos and Face Unlock work correctly. Privacy is another key consideration; if Photo Security is enabled, the kiosk should not expose employees’ photos in overly public or sensitive areas. Clear, printed instructions or signage next to the device are recommended so that new employees or visitors understand exactly how to use the kiosk. Together, these practices ensure usability, security, and respect for employee privacy.

content: This section covers advanced troubleshooting scenarios for the Time Kiosk. For PIN-related issues (such as an employee not receiving their PIN), it advises verifying that the employee’s registered email address and employment status are correct, and then resending or resetting the PIN if necessary. For Photo Security not working, it recommends checking camera permissions in the browser, testing the camera separately, and re-enabling Photo Security in kiosk settings before refreshing the page. For a kiosk that appears unresponsive, the steps include refreshing the browser tab, restarting the device, and checking for internet connectivity problems. A repeated or reappearing Activation Code can indicate that a previously activated kiosk configuration was deleted, in which case the device must be re-activated using a new Activation Code in Time Tracking Settings. These guidelines help admins quickly diagnose and correct the most common technical issues that affect kiosk usage.

section_title: Enable Time Tracking in Offline Mode
content: This section explains how to enable offline mode so employees can continue tracking time even when there is no internet connection. It describes that UZIO supports a limited set of offline actions for employee time tracking through the mobile app (and optionally kiosk, if supported). To enable this capability, an employer administrator logs into the employer portal, opens Time Tracking Settings from the left navigation, navigates to the Time Clocks area, and turns on the option that allows employees to track time without an internet connection. Once enabled, supported devices can capture punches offline while the system stores the actions locally until a connection is restored and syncing can occur.

section_title: What Actions Are Allowed in Offline Mode
content: This section lists what employees can and cannot do while using UZIO in offline mode. Offline capabilities are limited to core time tracking actions for employees who are already configured in Time Tracking and using the mobile app (and supported kiosk scenarios). Typically, employees can clock in, clock out, and record breaks while offline. Those actions are stored locally on the device with their timestamps and maintained in the correct sequence. More advanced actions, such as timesheet approvals, running reports, or syncing hours to payroll, are not available offline and require an active internet connection. The section clarifies that offline features are only available to employees who are active in Time Tracking and that administrative or high-impact tasks must still be performed online. This ensures that the offline mode focuses on essential punch capture while preserving data integrity and preventing complex changes without server validation.

section_title: How the System Works in Offline Mode
content: This section describes the internal behavior of UZIO when an employee is working offline. While offline, the app shows a visual indicator or tag such as “Offline” so that employees know they are not connected. Any clock in/out or break actions performed in this state are recorded in secure local storage on the mobile device, with their original timestamps and in the exact sequence in which they occurred. The system maintains the order of all offline actions. Once an internet connection is restored, the app automatically begins syncing the locally stored punches to the server, typically showing a progress indicator or sync status in a corner of the app. The syncing process sends each recorded offline action to the server to be inserted into the employee’s timesheet. If there are no conflicts, the entries appear as if they had been recorded online in real time.

content: This section explains what happens when there is a conflict between offline punches and the current server state after syncing. A conflict can occur if the employee’s timesheet was changed from another device or by a manager while the mobile app was offline, or if overlapping entries are detected when offline punches are posted. When such a conflict arises, the system displays a 'Conflict Detected' prompt in the mobile app, indicating which entry is in question and showing the version that exists on the server. The employee is prompted to resolve the conflict rather than the system making an automatic decision. Two options are provided: Edit and Discard. The section emphasizes that conflict resolution is a manual step and that the employee must choose how to reconcile differences so that time records remain accurate and consistent.

section_title: Edit Option for Resolving Offline Conflicts
content: This section focuses on the 'Edit' option offered when resolving offline time entry conflicts. If employees choose Edit, they are taken to a screen where they can manually adjust the conflicting time entry—changing the start or end time, duration, or other relevant details—to remove overlaps or align with the current server state. Once they save the corrected entry, the app syncs the updated record back to the server, and the conflict is marked as resolved. The section notes that this process is manual and may require employees to recall their actual worked times accurately. Depending on configuration, edited entries may also be flagged for manager approval. After a successful edit and sync, the entry appears in the timesheet like any other regular time entry.

section_title: Discard Option for Resolving Offline Conflicts
content: This section explains the 'Discard' option during offline conflict resolution. When an employee chooses Discard, they are telling the system to ignore the conflicting offline entry and keep the server’s version (or leave no new entry if the conflict was only on the offline side). The local record of that offline punch is removed, and the conflict flag is cleared. As a result, the employee’s timesheet reflects only approved or previously synced entries, and the discarded offline entry no longer appears on the timesheet page. The section highlights that Discard should be used when the offline entry is clearly incorrect or redundant and that employees should review carefully before discarding, since this action abandons the offline changes.
